modules.title: DeFi: Banking Without Banks
modules.description: Understanding what DeFi replaces, smart contracts as vending machines, and the new financial system

questions.question: What does 'DeFi' stand for?

options.text: Decentralized Finance - financial services without traditional intermediaries

questions.explanation: DeFi stands for Decentralized Finance. It's a system of financial services (lending, borrowing, trading, etc.) built on blockchain that operates without traditional banks, brokers, or financial institutions.

questions.question: Think of a vending machine: you put money in, press a button, and get a snack. No human involved. What crypto concept works similarly?

options.text: A smart contract - code that automatically executes when conditions are met

questions.explanation: Smart contracts are like vending machines for money. The code says 'if X happens, do Y' and executes automatically. No bank teller, no approval process - just transparent rules enforced by code.

questions.question: What traditional financial service does a 'DEX' replace?

options.text: A stock exchange or currency exchange - a place to trade assets

questions.explanation: DEX (Decentralized Exchange) replaces traditional exchanges. Instead of a company matching buyers and sellers and holding funds, smart contracts handle trades directly between users' wallets.

questions.question: What does a DeFi 'money market' or 'lending protocol' replace?

options.text: Bank savings accounts and loans - you can earn interest or borrow without a bank

questions.explanation: DeFi lending protocols let you deposit crypto to earn interest (like a savings account) or borrow against your crypto (like a loan), but without bank applications, credit checks, or bankers deciding if you qualify.

questions.question: Why is DeFi called 'permissionless'?

options.text: You don't need to be polite
Anyone with a wallet can use it - no applications, credit checks, or gatekeepers
You can do anything without consequences

questions.explanation: Permissionless means no one can stop you from participating. Traditional finance requires approval - bank account applications, credit checks, etc. DeFi just requires a wallet and funds. Open 24/7, globally accessible.

questions.question: What is 'composability' in DeFi, sometimes called 'money legos'?

options.text: Different DeFi protocols can connect and build on each other like building blocks

questions.explanation: Because DeFi protocols are open and interoperable, they can be combined like Lego blocks. Deposit to Protocol A, use that as collateral in Protocol B, use that to trade on Protocol C - all in one transaction.

questions.question: What makes DeFi 'non-custodial'?

options.text: You never have to store anything
You keep control of your assets - protocols don't hold your crypto, your wallet does

questions.explanation: Non-custodial means no third party holds your funds. When you use DeFi, your crypto stays in your wallet until you make a transaction. You maintain control rather than trusting a company to hold it.

questions.question: What role do smart contracts play in DeFi?

options.text: They're the automated code that runs financial services without human intermediaries

questions.explanation: Smart contracts are the backbone of DeFi. They're programs that automatically execute financial operations - lending, trading, interest distribution - without needing humans to process transactions.

questions.question: Why is transparency considered a feature of DeFi?

options.text: All transactions and code are public, so anyone can verify what's happening

questions.explanation: DeFi code is open-source and transactions are on public blockchains. You can verify exactly how a protocol works, see all transactions, and audit the rules yourself. No hidden fees or mysterious processes.

questions.question: What is 'TVL' (Total Value Locked) and why do people track it?

options.text: The total amount of crypto deposited in a DeFi protocol - a measure of adoption and trust

questions.explanation: TVL shows how much money users have deposited into a protocol. Higher TVL often indicates more trust and adoption. It's a common metric for comparing DeFi protocols, though it's not the only thing that matters.

questions.question: What is the main benefit of DeFi operating 24/7?

options.text: You have to watch it constantly
No waiting for banks to open - you can transact, borrow, or trade anytime

questions.explanation: Traditional finance stops on weekends and holidays. DeFi never closes. You can make trades, take loans, or earn interest at 3 AM on Christmas. The blockchain doesn't sleep.

questions.question: What is a 'DeFi wallet'?

options.text: A special wallet only for DeFi
Any self-custody wallet that can connect to DeFi applications
A wallet given to you by a DeFi company

questions.explanation: Any wallet that lets you interact with DeFi protocols (like MetaMask, Trust Wallet) is a 'DeFi wallet.' It's self-custody - you hold the keys and connect to applications when you want to use them.

questions.question: What is the main risk of using DeFi compared to traditional banks?

options.text: No deposit insurance, smart contract bugs, and you're responsible for your own security
The only risk is lower returns
You have to wear a uniform

questions.explanation: DeFi removes intermediaries but also their protections. No FDIC insurance, no customer service to fix mistakes, no refunds if code has bugs. You gain freedom but also full responsibility.

questions.question: What does it mean to 'connect your wallet' to a DeFi app?

options.text: Giving the app your seed phrase
Allowing the app to see your address and request transaction approvals
Transferring all funds to the app
Creating a new wallet on the app

questions.explanation: Connecting your wallet lets the app see your address and propose transactions. Your wallet asks you to approve each transaction - you maintain control. Never give apps your seed phrase; that's different and dangerous.

questions.question: Why do some people say DeFi could help the 'unbanked'?

options.text: Anyone with internet can access financial services without bank requirements

questions.explanation: Billions of people lack access to banks due to location, documentation, or minimum balance requirements. DeFi only needs internet and a wallet - potentially opening financial services to previously excluded populations.

modules.title: Swapping Tokens
modules.description: Understanding DEXs, liquidity pools, and how trading works without a traditional exchange

questions.question: What is a DEX (Decentralized Exchange)?

options.text: A platform for trading tokens without a central company holding your funds

questions.explanation: DEXs let you trade cryptocurrency directly from your wallet. Smart contracts handle the exchange - no company takes custody of your funds. You trade peer-to-contract (or peer-to-pool) rather than through a centralized order book.

questions.question: What is a 'liquidity pool' in simple terms?

options.text: A swimming pool at a crypto company
A pot of tokens that people deposit so others can trade against it

questions.explanation: Think of a liquidity pool as a big pot of two tokens (like ETH and USDC). When you want to trade, you swap with the pool instead of finding another person. People who add tokens to the pool earn fees from trades.

questions.question: Imagine a currency exchange booth at the airport, but it's a robot that's always open and anyone can deposit money to run it. What is this similar to?

options.text: A liquidity pool and AMM (Automated Market Maker)

questions.explanation: An AMM is like a robot currency booth. It holds tokens and automatically quotes prices based on supply and demand. Anyone can deposit tokens (become a liquidity provider) and earn from trades the robot processes.

questions.question: When you 'swap' tokens on a DEX, what actually happens?

options.text: Someone else sends you tokens directly
You send one token to a pool and receive another token back, with prices set by a formula
The DEX company converts your tokens
Nothing moves - it's just numbers changing

questions.explanation: When you swap, you're trading with a liquidity pool, not a person. You deposit Token A and withdraw Token B. The pool's smart contract calculates the exchange rate based on the ratio of tokens in the pool.

questions.question: What is 'slippage' in a DEX trade?

options.text: The difference between the expected price and the actual price you get

questions.explanation: Slippage is the price change between when you submit a trade and when it executes. Large trades in small pools cause more slippage because they significantly change the pool's token ratio, moving the price.

questions.question: Why might prices be slightly different on different DEXs for the same token?

options.text: Each DEX has different pools with different amounts of liquidity and trading activity

questions.explanation: Each DEX has its own liquidity pools with different amounts of tokens. Supply and demand in each pool determines price. Traders called 'arbitrageurs' help keep prices similar by profiting from differences.

questions.question: What is a 'Liquidity Provider' (LP)?

options.text: Someone who deposits tokens into a pool to enable trading, earning fees in return

questions.explanation: Liquidity Providers are regular users who deposit their tokens into pools. They earn a share of the trading fees generated when others swap against the pool. It's like being a mini market maker.

questions.question: What is a 'trading fee' on a DEX?

options.text: A fee to create an account
A small percentage of each trade that goes to liquidity providers
A fee paid to the blockchain developers
A fee paid to the government

questions.explanation: When you swap on a DEX, you pay a small fee (often 0.3% or less). This fee goes to liquidity providers as their reward for supplying the tokens. It's how they earn income for providing liquidity.

questions.question: What is a 'gas fee' when using a DEX?

options.text: A fee for running your car to the exchange
A fee paid to the blockchain network to process your transaction
A fee paid to the DEX company

questions.explanation: Gas fees are separate from trading fees. They pay the blockchain network (miners/validators) to process your transaction. Gas fees vary based on network congestion and are paid regardless of trade size.

questions.question: Why might you set a 'slippage tolerance' before swapping?

options.text: To set the maximum price change you'll accept - the trade fails if exceeded

questions.explanation: Slippage tolerance protects you. If you set 1% and the price moves more than 1% before your trade executes, the transaction fails rather than giving you a bad deal. It's a safety limit.

questions.question: What does 'token approval' mean before your first swap?

options.text: You permit the DEX's smart contract to access a specific token in your wallet

questions.explanation: Before a smart contract can move your tokens, you must 'approve' it. This is a safety feature - you control which contracts can interact with which tokens. Approval usually costs a small gas fee.

questions.question: What is a 'token pair' on a DEX?

options.text: The two tokens in a liquidity pool that can be traded for each other
A discount for buying two tokens

questions.explanation: A token pair is the two assets in a liquidity pool. ETH/USDC is a pair - you can swap ETH for USDC or USDC for ETH. The pool needs both tokens to function.

questions.question: Why is 'deep liquidity' considered good for traders?

options.text: More liquidity means you can make larger trades with less price impact (slippage)

questions.explanation: Deep liquidity means lots of tokens in the pool. Your trade is a smaller percentage of the total, so it moves the price less. A $1,000 trade in a $1 million pool causes less slippage than in a $10,000 pool.

questions.question: What's an advantage of DEXs over centralized exchanges?

options.text: You maintain custody of your funds until the trade executes - no depositing to an exchange

questions.explanation: On a CEX, you deposit funds to the exchange's wallet and trust them. On a DEX, funds stay in your wallet until the actual swap. You're not trusting a company with custody of your assets.

questions.question: What should you check before swapping a token you've never used before?

options.text: Verify the token contract address to ensure it's the real token, not a fake
Check if it's on social media

questions.explanation: Scammers create fake tokens with similar names. Always verify the contract address from the official source. A token named 'Ethereum' might not be real ETH. One wrong character in the address means a completely different (possibly scam) token.

modules.title: Earning With Your Crypto
modules.description: Lending basics, understanding yield, and being aware of DeFi risks

questions.question: What is 'yield' in DeFi?

options.text: The return or earnings you get from depositing or staking your crypto

questions.explanation: Yield is the return on your crypto investment, usually expressed as APY (Annual Percentage Yield). If you deposit $1,000 at 5% APY, you'd earn roughly $50 in a year from yield.

questions.question: How does lending in DeFi work?

options.text: You deposit crypto to a protocol; borrowers pay interest, which is shared with lenders like you

questions.explanation: DeFi lending protocols pool deposits from lenders. Borrowers take loans from the pool and pay interest. That interest is distributed to lenders proportionally. All handled automatically by smart contracts.

questions.question: What is APY?

options.text: Annual Percentage Yield - the total return including compound interest over a year

questions.explanation: APY (Annual Percentage Yield) shows what you'd earn in a year if rates stayed constant and earnings were reinvested. 10% APY on $1,000 means roughly $100 in a year, with compounding.

questions.question: Why do DeFi yields often change?

options.text: Supply and demand - rates adjust based on how much is deposited vs. borrowed

questions.explanation: DeFi rates are algorithmic. When lots of people want to borrow and few are lending, rates rise to attract lenders. When there's excess lending supply, rates fall. It's automatic market balancing.

questions.question: What is 'staking' in simple terms?

options.text: Locking up crypto to help secure a network or protocol, earning rewards in return

questions.explanation: Staking means committing your crypto to support a blockchain (helping validate transactions) or a protocol (providing security). In return, you earn staking rewards - similar to interest but from network participation.

questions.question: What does 'impermanent loss' mean for liquidity providers?

options.text: The potential loss from price changes while your tokens are in a liquidity pool

questions.explanation: When you provide liquidity and token prices change significantly, you might end up with less value than if you'd just held the tokens. It's 'impermanent' because it can reverse if prices return to the original ratio.

questions.question: Why do some DeFi protocols offer extremely high yields (like 100%+ APY)?

options.text: High yields often come with high risks - newer protocols, token rewards that may lose value, or unsustainable models

questions.explanation: Extremely high yields are usually red flags. They might come from token emissions (which can crash in value), unsustainable models, or desperate protocols. 'If it seems too good to be true, it probably is' applies here.

questions.question: What is 'smart contract risk'?

options.text: The risk of signing contracts you don't understand
The risk that bugs or vulnerabilities in the code could cause you to lose funds
The risk of smart people stealing your crypto

questions.explanation: Smart contracts are code, and code can have bugs. If there's a vulnerability, hackers can exploit it to steal funds. Even audited protocols have been hacked. This is a fundamental risk of DeFi.

questions.question: Why is it risky to put all your crypto into one DeFi protocol?

options.text: If that protocol is hacked or fails, you lose everything - diversification limits damage

questions.explanation: Even 'safe' protocols can be hacked, exploited, or face unforeseen problems. Spreading funds across multiple protocols means one failure doesn't wipe out everything. Don't put all eggs in one basket.

questions.question: What should you research before depositing into a DeFi protocol?

options.text: Audit history, team reputation, TVL, time in operation, and what could go wrong

questions.explanation: Research is crucial: Has it been audited? By whom? How long has it operated without incidents? What's the TVL? Is the team known? What are the specific risks? Understanding what you're using helps you make informed decisions.

questions.question: What is a 'stablecoin' yield, and why might it be lower than volatile token yields?

options.text: Yield earned on stablecoins - often lower because there's less risk and less demand to borrow
Yields are the same for all tokens

questions.explanation: Stablecoin yields are often lower because stablecoins are less volatile and there's less speculative demand to borrow them. Higher yields on volatile tokens compensate lenders for price risk.

questions.question: What does 'harvest' or 'claim' rewards mean?

options.text: Collecting the rewards your position has earned and adding them to your wallet

questions.explanation: When you earn yields, rewards often accumulate in the protocol. 'Harvesting' or 'claiming' means executing a transaction to move those earned tokens to your wallet. Note: claiming usually costs gas.

questions.question: Why should beginners start with smaller amounts in DeFi?

options.text: To learn how it works and understand the risks without exposing significant funds

questions.explanation: DeFi has a learning curve and real risks. Starting small lets you make mistakes cheaply, understand gas fees, see how protocols work, and build confidence before committing larger amounts.

questions.question: What is a 'rug pull' risk when farming yield on new tokens?

options.text: Project creators draining funds and disappearing, leaving your investment worthless

questions.explanation: New, unvetted protocols can be designed to steal funds. Creators might drain liquidity, manipulate token prices, or simply disappear. High yields on new projects often mask rug pull risks. Stick to established protocols when starting.

questions.question: After completing this beginner track, what's a good next step?

options.text: Continue to our intermediate courses for deeper knowledge, and practice with small amounts

questions.explanation: This introduction covered the basics, but DeFi is deep. Our intermediate courses go into lending protocols, liquidity provision, perpetual futures, and advanced strategies. Practice with small amounts while you continue learning.
